FeedItems.Title: View dependent packages on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
There are several ways to evaluate packages on NuGet.org, such as download statistics, update frequency, owner reputation, GitHub Usage, and more.
Today, we’re excited to announce that you can...

FeedItems.Title: Advanced search on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that NuGet.org now supports one of our top customer asks – advanced search! You can now use a multitude of sorting and filtering criteria to help find the best NuGet...

FeedItems.Title: NuGet.org will permanently remove support for TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on June 15th
FeedItems.Summary: Last November, we shared our two-stage plan for deprecating TLS 1.0/1.1 on NuGet.org in which we stated that the permanent removal of TLS 1.0/1.1 support would occur in April 2020. However, in April,...

FeedItems.Title: NuGet.org will continue to support TLS 1.0 and 1.1 until further notice
FeedItems.Summary: Last November, we shared our two-stage plan for deprecating TLS 1.0/1.1 on NuGet.org and actions you can take today to ensure your systems use TLS 1.2. In that post, we announced that NuGet.org would...

FeedItems.Title: Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org ‚Äì Stage 1
FeedItems.Summary: Last November, we shared our two-stage plan for deprecating TLS 1.0/1.1 on NuGet.org and actions you can take today to ensure your systems use TLS 1.2. In this post, we will go into more details and a...

FeedItems.Title: Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
co-authored by Scott Bommarito
At Microsoft, using the latest and secure encryption techniques is very important to us to ensure the security and privacy of our customers. TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1,...

FeedItems.Title: Deprecating packages on nuget.org
FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that nuget.org now supports package deprecation. This has been a long standing ask that will help the ecosystem use supported packages. As a package publisher on nuget.org,...

FeedItems.Title: NuGet Spring 2019 Roadmap
FeedItems.Summary: We published our last NuGet roadmap in June last year. Many of the features announced were major additions to NuGet and we have been hard at work to implement those over the last few months. In this...

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y] The header's orange "search" button does not have a contrast ratio of 3:1 or higher" (#8265) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Package icons show up in search results at certain browser window widths in narrow layouts" (#8264) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
At certain browser width (between "smartphone" and "tablet" layouts) package icons get displayed on search results page while they are not displayed in other narrow layouts.

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. On this URL https://www.nuget.org/packages
2. Make your browser window narrower until it switches to "smartphone" (the narrowest) layout.
3. Increase the window width slowly.
4. At certain window width (I think it is one certain window width) right when it is about to switch to tablet layout there would a point where package icons would appear while general layout is still "smartphone".

I had it reproed on 4k monitor with 150% scale set in display settings and 100% scale in the browser itself (Chromium Edge).

### Expected behavior
Since icons don't generally appear in both smartphone and tablet layouts, there shouldn't be a point between those where icons are displayed.

### Screenshots
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102933/95923156-c2735e80-0d69-11eb-9a14-d531c96aab17.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Cookies] Expire and set the domain of Google Analytics cookies" (#8263) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
- Expire Google Analytics cookies in a year;
- Set the domain, to avoid providing Google Analytics cookies in the status page.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Revert "survey banner (#8249)"" (#8262) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This reverts commit 53729e84f00372d0932e02212fcd98db19c5d500.

This change aim to deploy to prod on Monday, revert this commit to unblock currently deployment to prod

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8225s/123

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add underline for banner" (#8261) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Add underline with survey link
Less space between like you and the link

UI: 
![bannerfinal](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64443925/95898745-5f230580-0d44-11eb-8a1b-acdff84a3f55.PNG)


Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8225

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VSFeedback - The trust relationship could not be established for the SSL/TLS secure channel." (#8237) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/1204423/nugetÊó†Ê≥ïËÅîÁΩë.html)._ --- NuGet is not connected to the Internet. The nuget.org index of the source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json could not be loaded. There was an error sending the request. The underlying connection is closed: The trust relationship could not be established for the SSL/TLS secure channel. According to the authentication process, the remote certificate is invalid. --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 9/30/2020, 01:45 AM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[ReleasePrep][2020.10.09]NuGetGallery of dev into master" (#8254) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Change items: 
*add aria-live to read alter
*Add feature flags to OData $count endpoints (#8241)
*Enhance OData deprecation error message (#8242) 
*Path fix to dev (#8248)
*survey banner (#8249)
*Remove A/B test check for the package dependents feature (#8251)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet pack should catch incorrect omitting of the dot in version numbers" (#9215) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
For .NET 5, [we're going](https://github.com/dotnet/designs/pull/92) to reuse the existing `net` moniker. Due to our new versioning scheme (fixed schedule, major bump every year) we're only five years away from .NET 10. Developers might accidentally say `net10` when they really meant `net10.0`. We're planning to follow in the footsteps of .NET Core where project files will generally use a dot, even when it's not necessary (e.g. `net5.0`) but of course this won't prevent humans from dropping the `.0` either inadvertently or for aesthetics.

It was [suggested](https://github.com/dotnet/designs/pull/92#discussion_r383463597) to handle this as part of NuGet pack.

There are several ways to deal with that:

1. Generally warn when a dot is missing
2. Only warn on when the TFM is >= `net5.0` (regardless of whether there is an OS flavor or not)

The (1) is more correct but will cause a lot of noise, especially in .NET Framework projects where the ambiguity is irrelevant as the platform will remain at 4.x forever. So my preference would be something more targeted. Not sure (2) is the best way to address that but it seems to hit the sweet spot.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add an NuGet ETW event provider through event source. " (#10076) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Add support to collect ETW traces for NuGet telemetry events. 
This will enable telemetry collection outside Visual Studio process.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Package should include private lib assets from package ref" (#5103) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When building a NuGetizer package, if the project has PackageReferences with PrivateAssets=lib, then those references are copied to the output directory. However, they are not included in the the package.

This is important, for example, for msbuild tasks that depend on other assemblies and need them to be bundled alongside the tasks assembly.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-references-in-project-files#controlling-dependency-assets

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "(MSBuild) Restore does not respect IntermediateOutputPath" (#10119) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When a csproj has the `IntermediateOutputPath` property set (so that instead of `obj` a different folder will be used) the restore target will produce temporary files in `obj` instead of the declared `IntermediateOutputPath`.

This is not a problem for projects using `packages.config`. But it is for those using the `PackageReference` format.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: **MSBuild**

NuGet Version: 5.6.0.6591

VS version: 16.7.5

OS version: win10 v2004

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Clone and check out https://github.com/ite-klass/TestNugetRestoreBaseIntermediatePath
2. Execute `msbuild -t:restore TestNugetRestoreBaseIntermediatePath.sln`

The result is a dirty workspace. VS will also show the obj folder and files.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Pack includes content brought in through dependency packages into the current project's package (SDK based projects only)" (#8867) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): VS 2019 

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 3.0.100

VS version (if appropriate): 16.3.8

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Windows 10.0.14393 x64

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: -

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

I have been using the `PrivateAssets="all"` option for a long time. It works great for `PackageReference`. Now I needed to use some content file in my project and I could not achieve the desired behavior with `PrivateAssets="all"`. I want to build "base" package with one file `data.json` which should be consumed in "top" package but should not be exposed further to consumers of the "top" package.

My "base" package:
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>netstandard2.0</TargetFramework>
    <IncludeBuildOutput>false</IncludeBuildOutput>
    <GeneratePackageOnBuild>true</GeneratePackageOnBuild>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <Content Include="data.json">
      <PackagePath>contentFiles/any/any/data.json</PackagePath>
    </Content>
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```
The result seems to be good for me:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21261007/69996708-a573d980-1563-11ea-8069-bb275803e1fb.png)

My "top" package:
```xml
<Project>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="BasePackage" Version="1.0.0">
      <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
    </PackageReference>
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

The Result is unexpected for me:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21261007/69997235-bc66fb80-1564-11ea-8c80-23e46bfa7cdb.png)

Why is the file again in the content section? This file is a development dependency, some sort of settings file. The "base" package is a package with Roslyn analyzers and the settings file - `data.json`. I do not present the analyzers used for clarity. For them, `PrivateAssets` works as it should - they do not fall into the dependencies of the "base" package. But for the settings file - `data.json`, I can‚Äôt get the same behavior.

I spent a lot of time resolving this issue and it seems to me that I do not see any obvious solution, which is somewhere nearby. I will be very grateful for the advice.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Package Manager Console Depends on Solution Start-up Project" (#9880) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@BrianBu01 commented on [Tue, 03 Mar 2020 18:27:14 GMT](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/issues/42137)
**Version Used**: 

VS Professional 2019 v 16.4.5

**Steps to Reproduce**:

1. Select a start up project
2. In Package Manager Console, select a default project different from startup
3. Run a command that depends on building of projects or even code with in such as Scaffold-DbContext.

**Expected Behavior**:

The command runs in context of the default project

**Actual Behavior**:

The command run on the default project but in the context of the start-up project
**Notes**

Not really sure that this is a bug, but it is a confusing coupling between two different concepts.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The task factory "***" could not be found in the assembly "***"" (#10109) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I am trying to make nuget package with some task. But I ran into a problem:
`The task factory "NuGetLibrary.Tasks.MyTask" could not be found in the assembly "C:\Users\Den\.nuget\packages\nugetlibrary\2.0.0-alpha.637374840513886857\build\netstandard2.1\..\..\lib\netstandard2.1\NuGetLibrary.dll"`.

```
Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2019 Preview
Version 16.8.0 Preview 3.2
```

NuGetLibrary.nuspec
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2010/07/nuspec.xsd">
    <metadata>
        <id>NuGetLibrary</id>
        <version>2.0.0-alpha.$timestamp$</version>
        
        <owners>Den</owners>
        <authors>Den</authors>
        <title>NuGet Library</title>
        <icon>Icon.png</icon>
        <description>Example package</description>
        <tags></tags>
        <projectUrl>https://github.com/</projectUrl>
        <repository type="git" url="https://github.com/" />
        
        <developmentDependency>true</developmentDependency>
        <packageTypes>
            <packageType name="Dependency" />
        </packageTypes>

        <!--<frameworkReferences>
            <group targetFramework=".NETStandard">
            </group>
        </frameworkReferences>-->
        
        <!--<frameworkAssemblies>
        </frameworkAssemblies>-->
        
        <!--<dependencies>
            <group targetFramework=".NETStandard" >
                <dependency id="Microsoft.Build.Utilities.Core" version="16.6.0" />
            </group>
        </dependencies>-->
        
        <!--<references>
            <group targetframework=".netstandard" >
            </group>
        </references>-->
        
        <contentFiles>
            <files include="**/*.*" buildAction="None" copyToOutput="false" flatten="false" />
        </contentFiles>
    </metadata>
    <files>
        <file src="Readme.txt" target="" />
        <file src="Icon.png" target="" />
        <file src="Build/NuGetLibrary.targets" target="build/netstandard2.1/" />
        <file src="bin/$configuration$/netstandard2.1/NuGetLibrary.dll" target="lib/netstandard2.1/" />
        <file src="bin/$configuration$/netstandard2.1/NuGetLibrary.pdb" target="lib/netstandard2.1/" />
        <file src="bin/$configuration$/netstandard2.1/NuGetLibrary.deps.json" target="lib/netstandard2.1/" />
        <file src="Content/Images/Image.jpg" target="contentFiles/any/netstandard2.1/Images/" />
    </files>
</package>
```

NuGetLibrary.targets
```
<Project xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003">
    <UsingTask TaskName="MyTask" AssemblyFile = "$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)..\..\lib\netstandard2.1\NuGetLibrary.dll" TaskFactory="NuGetLibrary.Tasks.MyTask" />
    <Target Name="BeforeBuild_" BeforeTargets="BeforeBuild">
        <Message Text="Hello World !!!" Importance="high" />
        <MyTask />
    </Target>
    <Target Name="AfterBuild_" AfterTargets="AfterBuild">
        <Message Text="Hello World !!!" Importance="high" />
        <MyTask />
    </Target>
</Project>
```

MyTask.cs
```
namespace NuGetLibrary.Tasks {
    using System;
    using System.Collections.Generic;
    using System.Text;
    using Microsoft.Build.Framework;
    using Microsoft.Build.Utilities;

    public class MyTask : Task {

        public override bool Execute() {
            Log.LogWarning( "MyTask !!!" );
            return true;
        }

    }
}
```
And the project itself.
[NuGetLibrary.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/5326326/NuGetLibrary.zip)

What am I doing wrong?
